ai-mn63:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn63:2.1_0: Then as Venerable Māluṅkyaputta was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
ai-mn63:2.2_0: “There are several convictions that the Buddha has left undeclared; he has set them aside and refused to comment on them.
ai-mn63:2.3_0: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
ai-mn63:2.4_0: The Buddha does not give me a straight answer on these points.
ai-mn63:2.5_0: I don’t like that, and do not accept it.
ai-mn63:2.6_0: I’ll go to him and ask him about this.
ai-mn63:2.7_0: If he gives me a straight answer on any of these points,
ai-mn63:2.8_0: the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal ...
ai-mn63:2.9_0: ‘a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.’
ai-mn63:2.10_0: I will lead the spiritual life under him.
ai-mn63:2.11_0: If he does not give me a straight answer on any of these points,
ai-mn63:2.12_0: the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal ...
ai-mn63:2.13_0: ‘a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.’
ai-mn63:2.14_0: I shall resign the training and return to a lesser life.”
ai-mn63:3.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, Māluṅkyaputta came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
ai-mn63:3.1_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:

ai-mn63:7.1_0: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
ai-mn63:7.2_0: and what I have declared as declared.
ai-mn63:7.3_0: And what have I not declared?

ai-mn63:8.1_0: And why have I not declared these things?
ai-mn63:8.2_0: Because they aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
